newsitem.title: CHILE: Software piracy found to be widespread in Latam.
newsitem.headline: Software piracy found to be widespread in Latam.

text.p: Nearly seven out of every 10 computer software programs sold in Latin America are illegal copies, according to a study conducted by Price Waterhouse and released on Thursday.
"The results of our study show that of every 100 copies of software sold in Latin America, 68 are pirated," Price Waterhouse researcher Guillermo Beuchat told reporters.

In some countries, more than 90 percent of software sales involve pirated copies, though the overall rate in Latin American falls short of that in Eastern Europe, where 80 percent of computer software is pirated, the study said.
By comparison, 28 percent of computer software programs sold in North America are pirated, 43 percent in Western Europe and 74 percent in the Middle East, the study said.

Sales of illegal copies of software totaled about $911 million in Latin America last year, according to a study by a trade group known as the Business Software Alliance. The figure was cited in the Price Waterhouse report.

Pirating rates are highest in Central America, where 92 percent of programs sold in El Salvador were illegal copies and 90 percent in Guatemala. Costa Rica, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago are not far behind.
Argentina, which is engaged in a trade dispute with the United States over intellectual property laws, has a pirating rate of about 70 percent. Brazil's rate is about 68 percent, the study said.
The lowest pirating rates in the region are in Chile, with 62 percent and Panama at 65 percent, the study said.
Software piracy cost Latin American governments about $5 billion in lost tax receipts and nearly 115,000 jobs, Beuchat said.
